title: How to Feast

steps.headline: Eat less in the 48 hours before the meal.
steps.description: Leading up to your feast, you'll want to make room for the extra food. Fasting is not recommended, as it can be dangerous, but strive to eat smaller portions. Stick to tiny meals throughout the day and avoid sodium, which can cause bloating. Have tiny meals like fruit and yogurt, hard boiled eggs, and small salads.

steps.headline: Avoid water and breakfast in the morning.
steps.description: While skipping breakfast is usually not a great idea, it's okay if you're going to be indulging a bit later in the day. While you should have a small amount of water to stay hydrated, make sure not to consume too much liquid either. This can fill up your stomach, making it difficult to indulge later on.

steps.headline: Have something sour just before eating.
steps.description: Nothing can dampen the fun of a feast like indigestion. Sour foods help aid in digestion, so eat something small and sour just before the meal. Try mixing a small amount of apple cider vinegar in water and drinking it, for example.

steps.headline: Wear loose-fitting clothing.
steps.description: Eating large meals can make the body bloat, so wear loose clothes when attending the feast. Things like sweat pants, looser t-shirts, and loose dresses are great attire for a feast.

steps.headline: Eat outdoors if possible.
steps.description: Many medieval feasts were held outdoors. See if you can set up in someone's backyard and eat around something like a fire pit. If it's not too chilly outside, an outdoor meal can really set the feast atmosphere.

steps.headline: Set food out on buffets.
steps.description: Invest in a large buffet table for a feast. Feasts throughout history were often served buffet style. You can even place food in the center of a longer table and have guests serve themselves while seated. If you don't have a buffet, try pushing together several small tables and covering them with a tablecloth.

steps.headline: Choose a luscious centerpiece.
steps.description: Many historical feasts were marked with a centerpiece. A large floral centerpiece, comprised of green plants like ivy, is a must to set the tone for a feast. Branches and feathers were frequently used in medieval times, so consider using these as well. Sweet smelling flowers were often used in centerpieces, so opt for flowers like lilacs, violets, and sweet peas. To add the luscious medieval greenery, herbs like mint, thyme, and sage can add some bright green to your flower arrangement. You can buy a centerpiece from a local flower shop if you don't want to make one yourself.

steps.headline: Add decorations.
steps.description: Have some fun medieval decorations to set a feast vibe. Tall candles can be great for a buffet table, but you can also make your own decorations. Try making medieval shields out of cardboard paper and construction paper, for example, or buying plastic cups and painting them gold to help them resemble goblets. Try browsing sites like Pinterest and YouTube for fun craft ideas.

steps.headline: Serve some non-conventional meats.
steps.description: Standard meats like chicken, beef, pork, and fish can certainly be served at a feast. However, try some more indulgent meats you would not normally purchase. Lamb, duck, venison, rabbit, and pheasant were often served historically for feats. Go to a local butcher's shop before your feast and pick up some fancier meat for the occasion. You can look up recipes for cooking unconventional meats online. You can also simply purchase pre-cooked meats from a local restaurant.

steps.headline: Provide many different sauces.
steps.description: Historically, feasts included a wide variety of sauces meant to be poured over meat and other side dishes. You can buy elegant sauces from a gourmet grocery shop or make them at home. Fruit-based sauces, such as cranberry sauce, are a popular option for feasts. You can also try cream-based sauces, as these are particularly indulgent.

steps.headline: Serve high quality side dishes with a variety of options.
steps.description: Have some fun when making side dishes, as lavish side dishes are important to a feast. Add a twist with standard vegetables sides. Try something like Brussels sprouts wrapped in bacon or dates stuffed with goat cheese. Fruit was a popular dish at feasts, and was often seasoned with cinnamon and honey. You can either buy fancier side dishes from a local restaurant or make them yourself at home prior to a feast.

steps.headline: Have a dessert table.
steps.description: Pies, pastries, sweetened fruits, and puddings are popular dishes for a feast. Near the end of your buffet table, or on a separate table, have desserts. You can buy desserts from a local bakery. It can also be fun to have everyone attending the feast make their own dessert for the occasion.

steps.headline: Provide beverages.
steps.description: Alcoholic beverages can include things like champagne, sangria, and wine. For non-drinkers, sparkling water gives off a fancy, feast-like vibe. You can serve tea and coffee with dessert.

steps.headline: Eat bitter appetizers to stimulate digestion.
steps.description: Grab foods with a bitter flavor when indulging in appetizers before the big meal. This can help stimulate digestion, keeping you comfortable throughout the meal. Go for vegetable based appetizers like olives, salads, broccoli, and cauliflower.

steps.headline: Add fresh herbs to your foods.
steps.description: If herbs are provided as a side, sprinkle them over your food as you eat. Try putting sage over turkey, rosemary over yam, and fresh mint or oregano on salad. Herbs also aid in digestion, allowing you to enjoy your meal without becoming uncomfortable.

steps.headline: Savor each bite.
steps.description: Eat slowly as you feast. This will allow you to truly enjoy the indulgence of feasting. Savor each bite and try to chew your food slowly. Be aware of the flavors and textures, striving to really enjoy the meal.

steps.headline: Try different flavors.
steps.description: Sprinkle a variety of sauces over your meat and vegetables, for example. Take a tiny serving of every type of meat, vegetable, and side dish that's served. Try a little bit of everything so you truly enjoy your meal.

steps.headline: Eat until you're comfortably full.
steps.description: Usually, it's recommended you stop eating before you feel too full. However, a feast means overindulging a little. Feel free to keep eating until you feel very full, to the point you're no longer interested in food. While it's fun to overeat for a feast, if you end up uncomfortably full, this can put a damper on your meal.

steps.headline: Have some tea after the meal to help with digestion.
steps.description: You want to leave a feast feeling happy and satisfied. A bit of tea, especially peppermint or fennel tea, can really help with digestion. After dinner and dessert, have a cup of tea and chat with guests.
